To verify the relationship between volta.objective: To verify the relationship between voltage (V), current (I), and resistance (R) in an electrical circuit, as expressed by Ohm's Law (V = IR).
materials: Conductor: A Nichrome wire or any other suitable resistor.
Voltmeter: To measure the potential difference (voltage).
Ammeter: To measure the electric current.
Connecting Wires: For connecting the components in the circuit.
Key/Switch: To control the flow of current.
Dry Cell or Battery Eliminator: To supply the electrical power.
Battery Holder: To hold the dry cell or battery eliminator.
Sandpaper: To clean the ends of the connecting wires.
Graph Paper: For plotting the graph between voltage (V) and current (I).
Rheostat: To vary the resistance in the circuit.

Setup the Circuit: - Connect one end of the Nichrome wire to the positive terminal of the battery holder.
- Connect the other end of the Nichrome wire to one terminal of the ammeter.
- Connect the other terminal of the ammeter to one terminal of the voltmeter.
- Connect the other terminal of the voltmeter to the negative terminal of the battery holder.
- Insert the key in series with the circuit to control the flow of current.
Measure Voltage and Current: - Close the key to complete the circuit.
- Note down the reading of the potential difference (voltage) from the voltmeter and the electric current from the ammeter.
- Calculate the ratio of Potential Difference/Electric Current (V/I).
Vary the Resistance: - Use a rheostat to vary the resistance in the circuit in increments of 1 ohm, starting from 2 ohms up to 10 ohms.
- Repeat the measurements for each value of resistance.
Plot the Graph: - Plot a graph between voltage (V) and current (I).
- The graph should be a straight line, verifying Ohm's Law.
